page.title: 03Forestry.
page.content: Beech is thought of as the traditional wood of these Cotswold slopes but there is a long tradition of interplanting conifers. A description of the Dillay Brook Valley in 1900 stated that the area was dominated by stately Scots pine-whereas there are now few,if any,to be found.It would seem that the Scots pine was cleared, as many of these woods were,during the First and Second World Wars, leaving the beech to dominate.Since the wartime clearances there has been a mixture of natural regeneration and coniferous plantation.Before 1965 and myxomatosis,rabbits were a big problem and fenced plantations were generally more successful. Much of the woodland is managed by forestry groups but Blackstable Wood in the N.E. will shortly be going over to National Trust ownership.
